attributes.description:
This section helps assess compliance with CCI-000213 by verifying that only approved, authorized users are accessing system resources. These visualizations are designed to detect and highlight any logical access attempts by users who are not explicitly on the approved list for a given component.

**How an analyst can use it:**
To perform a component-level compliance assessment, use the global filters at the top of the dashboard. For instance, apply a filter like 'host.name: <your_component_name>' to focus on a specific server or endpoint. Review the visualizations to identify any access events (successful or failed) initiated by users not defined in your access control policy. A non-zero count in the 'Total Unauthorized Access Attempts' visualization is an immediate indicator of a potential policy violation that requires investigation. Use the trend and detailed tables to understand the context and specifics of each unauthorized event.
attributes.title: [CCI-000213] Enforce Approved Authorizations
attributes.visState: {"title":"[CCI-000213] Enforce Approved Authorizations","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"fontSize":12,"markdown":"# [CCI-000213] [AC.L1-3.1]  Enforce Approved Authorizations\n\n### Verify logical access controls are enforced per policy.","openLinksInNewTab":false}}

attributes.description: This visualization displays the health status for CCI-000213 by monitoring anomaly scores from its associated Machine Learning job. The background color reflects the highest anomaly score related to unauthorized access attempts, providing a quick assessment of compliance. A high score indicates a significant deviation from normal user access patterns, signaling a potential policy violation that requires investigation.
attributes.title: [CCI-000213] Enforce Approved Authorizations ML

attributes.description:
This visualization displays the total count of logical access attempts by users not on the authorized list.

**Why this visualization works:**
It provides an immediate, high-level indicator of a potential compliance failure. A single count greater than zero means an unauthorized user has attempted to access a resource, which directly contradicts the access control policy.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Monitor this number as a primary health check. If the count is anything other than zero, it signifies that further investigation is required. Use this as a starting point to pivot to the trend and detailed event visualizations to understand the scope and nature of the policy violation.

query.query: (event.action: ("session_start" OR "user_login" OR "user_authentication" OR "sudo_start") OR event.category: (authentication OR session) OR winlog.event_id: (4624 OR 4625 OR 4648 OR 4672)) AND NOT user.name: (root OR *system* OR *administrator* OR "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" OR "-" OR *service_account* OR *authorized_user*)

attributes.title: [CCI-000213] Total Unauthorized Access Attempts Number

attributes.description:
This table provides a detailed breakdown of individual unauthorized access events.

**Why this visualization works:**
It offers the most granular level of detail, which is essential for forensic investigation. An analyst can see the exact timestamp, source, destination, user, and process involved in a potential policy violation, which is crucial for determining root cause and impact.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Use this table as the final step in an investigation. Sort by '@timestamp' to see the most recent events. Filter by a specific 'user.name' or 'host.name' identified in the other visualizations. Examine the 'process.name', 'source.ip', and 'event.outcome' fields to understand precisely what happened, whether it was successful, and where it came from. This information is critical for any incident response or compliance reporting.

query.query: (event.action: ("session_start" OR "user_login" OR "user_authentication" OR "sudo_start") OR event.category: (authentication OR session) OR winlog.event_id: (4624 OR 4625 OR 4648 OR 4672)) AND NOT user.name: (github OR ftpuser OR *admin* OR root OR *system* OR *administrator* OR "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" OR "-" OR *service_account* OR *authorized_user*)

attributes.title: [CCI-000213] Detailed Unauthorized Access Events Table

attributes.description:
This table provides a detailed breakdown of individual unauthorized access events.

**Why this visualization works:**
It offers the most granular level of detail, which is essential for forensic investigation. An analyst can see the exact timestamp, source, destination, user, and process involved in a potential policy violation, which is crucial for determining root cause and impact.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Use this table as a control. Compare this table to the UNAUTHORIZED table and assure that you are looking at the correct unauthorizations. Sort by '@timestamp' to see the most recent events. Filter by a specific 'user.name' or 'host.name' identified in the other visualizations. Examine the 'process.name', 'source.ip', and 'event.outcome' fields to understand precisely what happened, whether it was successful, and where it came from. This information is critical for any incident response or compliance reporting.

query.query: (event.action: ("session_start" OR "user_login" OR "user_authentication" OR "sudo_start") OR event.category: (authentication OR session) OR winlog.event_id: (4624 OR 4625 OR 4648 OR 4672)) AND user.name: (github OR ftpuser OR *admin* OR root OR *system* OR *administrator* OR "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" OR "-" OR *service_account* OR *authorized_user*)

attributes.title: [CCI-000213] Detailed AUTHORIZED Access Events Table

attributes.description:
This visualization displays a time-series trend of logical access attempts from unauthorized users.

**Why this visualization works:**
It helps an analyst understand the magnitude and timeline of unauthorized access. A sudden spike might indicate a brute-force attack or a misconfiguration, while a low, consistent level of attempts could point to a persistent but stealthy adversary or a recurring policy misunderstanding.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Look for spikes or any consistent, non-zero baseline of activity. Hover over data points to see the count of unauthorized attempts at a specific time. Use the time range selector to zoom in on periods of high activity to correlate with other events or begin a more focused investigation.

query.query: (event.action: ("session_start" OR "user_login" OR "user_authentication" OR "sudo_start") OR event.category: (authentication OR session) OR winlog.event_id: (4624 OR 4625 OR 4648 OR 4672)) AND NOT user.name: (github OR ftpuser OR *admin* OR root OR *system* OR *administrator* OR "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" OR "-" OR *service_account* OR *authorized_user*)

attributes.title: [CCI-000213] Unauthorized Access Attempts Trend (converted)

attributes.description:
This visualization breaks down the unauthorized access attempts by the user accounts that initiated them.

**Why this visualization works:**
It immediately answers the question 'Who is attempting unauthorized access?' By visualizing the top offenders, it helps prioritize an investigation. A single user with many attempts is a different investigative path than many users with single attempts.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Review the chart to identify which user accounts are responsible for unauthorized access attempts. Pay special attention to any unexpected or highly active accounts. Use this information to guide your investigation, such as reviewing the permissions and recent activity of the identified users.

query.query: (event.action: ("session_start" OR "user_login" OR "user_authentication" OR "sudo_start") OR event.category: (authentication OR session) OR winlog.event_id: (4624 OR 4625 OR 4648 OR 4672)) AND NOT user.name: (github OR ftpuser OR *admin* OR root OR *system* OR *administrator* OR "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" OR "-" OR *service_account* OR *authorized_user*)

attributes.title: [CCI-000213] Top Unauthorized Users
